Def.Name: Mountain Maple
Def.Description: A small tree or shrub not over 30 feet in height; small, irregular crown of upright branches; trunk, often crooked and divided, up to 7" diameter.
Def.Leaves: Leaves are three-lobed, rarely five-lobed, 2 1/2" — 4 1/4" long, yellowish-green above, and hairy beneath. Leaf margins have coarse, irregular teeth, and usually have fine hairs beneath with smooth surface above. Foliage is light to yellowish-green in color. Deep red or orange in autumn.
Def.Twigs: Yellowish-green to reddish-green with gray hairs; terminal buds, red, perched on a small stalk, 2 scales.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Samara, 3/4" - 1" long, has wings that diverge at right angles and mature in September.
Def.Bark: The color of young bark is green and does not have stripes. Older bark reddish-brown to brown with stripes or slighly furrowed.
Def.Range: Native to northeastern North America from Saskatchewan to Newfoundland, Minnesota and south to Pennsylvania. It also grows at high elevations in the southern Appalachian Mountains to northern Georgia.
Def.Remarks: The tree lives in moist woods in rich, well-drained soils on rocky hillsides and along streams. It also grows on ravines, cliff faces, and forested bogs. During ecological succession, it colonizes the understory as pioneer species die.
